P.title: Will a new AI-driven epidemiology tool predict the next global pandemic with over 90% accuracy before 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, a new AI-driven epidemiology tool is developed and successfully predicts the next global pandemic with over 90% accuracy. The prediction must be specific to the pathogen type (e.g., virus, bacteria), its origin, and the timeframe of outbreak. The tool's prediction accuracy must be verified by a consensus of at least three leading health organizations (e.g., WHO, CDC, ECDC) or by publication in at least three peer-reviewed scientific journals. The tool must be publicly acknowledged by these organizations or publications as having met the 90% accuracy threshold in its prediction. In the event of multiple tools meeting these criteria, the resolution will be based on the first tool to be publicly acknowledged as meeting the accuracy threshold. Predictions made retrospectively, after the pandemic has begun, do not count towards this question's resolution.

Q.title: Will the widespread adoption of COVID-19 vaccines lead to a permanent change in workplace dynamics by 2030?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, there is a significant and permanent change in workplace dynamics directly attributable to the widespread adoption of COVID-19 vaccines. Significant change is defined as:
- A permanent increase of at least 20% in the number of employees working remotely or in hybrid models compared to pre-pandemic levels (2019).
- The implementation of permanent flexible working hours by at least 50% of Fortune 500 companies.
- The establishment of permanent health and safety protocols in the workplace, including but not limited to vaccination requirements, that were not standard prior to the pandemic.

Changes must be documented by credible sources, including but not limited to surveys by major human resources consultancies (e.g., Deloitte, PwC), reports from reputable news organizations (BBC, The New York Times, The Guardian), or official statements from companies. Temporary measures or changes solely due to government mandates that are lifted do not count towards this question's resolution.

- The implementation of permanent flexible working hours by at least 50% of Fortune 500 companies.
- The establishment of permanent health and safety protocols in the workplace, including but not limited to vaccination requirements, that were not standard prior to the pandemic.

Changes must be documented by credible sources, including but not limited to surveys by major human resources consultancies (e.g., Deloitte, PwC), reports from reputable news organizations (BBC, The New York Times, The Guardian), or official statements from companies. Temporary measures or changes solely due to government mandates that are lifted do not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will a significant discovery in particle physics be made through computational methods by 2030?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a significant discovery in particle physics is made through computational methods. A "significant discovery" is defined as a discovery that leads to a substantial revision of the Standard Model of particle physics, or provides empirical evidence for phenomena not predicted by the Standard Model, such as supersymmetry, extra dimensions, or dark matter interactions.

The discovery must be confirmed through publication in a peer-reviewed scientific journal of high impact (e.g., Nature, Science, Physical Review Letters) and must be recognized by a leading scientific organization in the field of particle physics (e.g., CERN, Fermilab, International Particle Physics Outreach Group).

Computational methods include, but are not limited to, simulations, data analysis algorithms, and machine learning techniques. The use of computational methods must be central to the discovery, not merely supplementary.

In the event of multiple discoveries, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one meets the above criteria.

Q.title: Will advancements in string theory lead to a breakthrough in nuclear fusion technology by 2040?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2040, advancements in string theory have directly contributed to a significant breakthrough in nuclear fusion technology. A "significant breakthrough" is defined as a development that enables a nuclear fusion reactor to achieve and maintain net positive energy output for at least 24 continuous hours. The breakthrough must be attributable to theoretical or practical applications of string theory, as confirmed by publication in a peer-reviewed scientific journal or an official announcement from a leading nuclear fusion research institution (e.g., ITER, National Ignition Facility, or similar). In the absence of direct evidence linking the breakthrough to string theory, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The breakthrough must represent a substantial improvement over current capabilities and not merely an incremental advancement.

P.title: Will the United States lead the world in quantum computing technology development by 2030?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the United States is recognized as the global leader in the development of quantum computing technology. Leadership will be determined based on the following criteria:

- Number of quantum computers developed that surpass the capabilities of existing classical computers in significant computational tasks (quantum supremacy).
- Volume and impact of peer-reviewed scientific publications originating from the United States that contribute to quantum computing technology.
- Investment in quantum computing research and development by both the public and private sectors in the United States, compared to other countries.

Global leadership must be recognized by at least two of the following authoritative sources: the International Quantum Computing Association, the IEEE Quantum Computing Task Force, or significant coverage in at least three major technology or science news outlets (e.g., Wired, MIT Technology Review, Nature).

In the event of a dispute over leadership, the consensus among these sources will be considered definitive.

Q.title: Will China implement a comprehensive legal framework for regulating artificial intelligence by 2025?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, China has officially implemented a comprehensive legal framework for the regulation of artificial intelligence (AI). The framework must cover at least the following areas: 
- Ethical use of AI
- Data privacy and protection
- AI in public surveillance
- Autonomous vehicles
- AI in healthcare
The implementation of such a framework must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. 
For the purpose of this question, a "comprehensive legal framework" is defined as a set of laws or regulations that collectively address the ethical, social, economic, and technical aspects of AI deployment and use across multiple sectors. 
In the event of partial implementation (e.g., regulations covering only certain sectors), the question will resolve as No unless the missing sectors are explicitly stated to be covered in a subsequent phase of implementation.

P.title: Will AI technology play a crucial role in understanding dark matter by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, AI technology has played a crucial role in a significant breakthrough in understanding dark matter. A "crucial role" is defined as AI technology being instrumental in the analysis, interpretation, or discovery process leading to the breakthrough. The breakthrough must be recognized by the scientific community, evidenced by publication in a peer-reviewed scientific journal or an official announcement by a major scientific organization (e.g., CERN, NASA, ESA). The use of AI must be explicitly mentioned as a key component in the discovery or analysis process. In the event of multiple contributions to understanding dark matter, this question will resolve as Yes if AI's role is deemed critical by consensus in the scientific community or through acknowledgment in multiple peer-reviewed publications.

Q.title: Will a quantum computing breakthrough lead to a significant advancement in solving complex natural science problems by 2030?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a breakthrough in quantum computing results in a significant advancement in solving complex natural science problems, such as those in physics, chemistry, biology, or earth sciences. A "significant advancement" is defined as a solution or substantial progress on a problem that has been widely recognized as unsolved or intractable with classical computing methods. The breakthrough must be documented in a peer-reviewed scientific journal or recognized by a leading scientific organization or consortium. In the absence of a single defining event, a consensus among experts in the field, as reported by at least three reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post), will be considered sufficient evidence. The advancement must be directly attributable to the capabilities of quantum computing, rather than incremental improvements in classical computing or other technologies.

P.title: Will North Korea announce a formal initiative to address climate change by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, North Korea has officially announced a formal initiative to address climate change. The initiative must be aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions, promoting renewable energy, or other significant environmental protection measures. The announcement must come from an official government source or be confirmed by at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters). In the absence of a direct announcement, credible evidence of the initiative's implementation (e.g., legislative action, funding allocation) reported by these sources will also result in a Yes resolution. Initiatives that are purely rhetorical without concrete actions or plans will not count towards this question's resolution.

Q.title: Will there be a significant scientific discovery that influences US environmental policy by 2025?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a significant scientific discovery is made that directly influences United States environmental policy. A "significant scientific discovery" is defined as a discovery that leads to the enactment of new legislation, significant amendment of existing legislation, or a major shift in policy direction at the federal level. The discovery must be related to environmental science and must be recognized as significant by the scientific community, as evidenced by publication in a peer-reviewed scientific journal or endorsement by a major scientific organization. The influence on policy must be clearly attributable to the discovery, as confirmed by official government documentation or statements from relevant policymakers. In the absence of direct government confirmation, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, The Washington Post) will be considered sufficient evidence of the discovery's impact on policy. Temporary measures or executive orders that do not lead to lasting policy change do not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will SpaceX's Starship enable the commercialization of space travel by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, SpaceX has officially begun commercial operations of its Starship spacecraft for the purpose of space travel accessible to non-governmental, paying customers. Commercialization is defined as offering and conducting paid space travel services to individuals or private entities beyond governmental or scientific missions. The service must be operational, with at least one commercial flight completed. Confirmation must come from an official SpaceX announcement or credible media reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). In the event of a partial service offering (e.g., limited to specific routes or types of customers), the question will resolve as Yes if the service is intended for broader public availability. Temporary or promotional one-off flights do not count towards this question's resolution.

Q.title: Will SpaceX establish a permanent human settlement on Mars before 2040?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2040, SpaceX has established a permanent human settlement on Mars. A "permanent human settlement" is defined as a self-sustaining habitat capable of supporting human life indefinitely without requiring constant resupply from Earth. The settlement must include living quarters, life support systems, and facilities for at least 10 people. The establishment of the settlement must be confirmed by SpaceX through an official announcement or documentation. P.title: Will France implement a nationwide carbon-neutral initiative by 2030?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, France has officially implemented a nationwide initiative that is recognized as carbon-neutral. The initiative must encompass actions across multiple sectors, including but not limited to energy, transportation, industry, and agriculture, aimed at achieving a net-zero carbon footprint for the country.

The initiative must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient.

For the purpose of this question, "carbon-neutral" means that any carbon emissions produced by France are balanced by an equivalent amount of carbon sequestration or offsetting measures, within the same calendar year. The verification of carbon neutrality must be conducted by an independent, internationally recognized environmental organization.

In the event of partial implementation (e.g., limited to specific regions or sectors), the question will resolve as Yes only if there is a clear, government-confirmed plan for nationwide coverage by the end of 2030.

A "major shift" in global climate policy is defined as the adoption of new, substantial climate policies or amendments to existing policies by at least three of the following entities: the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), the European Union, the United States, China, and India. A "groundbreaking study" is defined as research that presents novel findings with the potential to substantially alter the understanding or management of public health. A "major shift" in public health policies refers to the implementation of new policies or significant amendments to existing policies, directly attributable to the study's findings. The shift must be officially announced by the government or a recognized public health authority in the respective country. In the absence of an official announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) are sufficient to confirm the policy shift. The resolution will consider only changes that have a broad impact on public health, excluding minor adjustments or policies affecting only specific groups.

P.title: Will advancements in microbiology influence global health policies more than technology by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, advancements in microbiology have had a more significant influence on global health policies than technological advancements. Influence on global health policies is defined as the adoption of new or revised policies, guidelines, or recommendations by at least three of the following organizations: World Health Organization (WHO), Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC), or similar national or international health bodies. The influence of microbiology advancements is measured by the direct citation of microbiological research or data in the formulation of these policies. Technological advancements include, but are not limited to, developments in medical devices, health information technologies, and biotechnology. The comparison between the influences of microbiology and technology will be assessed based on the number of policies influenced, the scope of the impact, and the depth of the changes implemented. In the event of ambiguity or lack of clear evidence, the question will resolve as No.

Q.title: Will the World Health Organization declare a global health emergency due to climate-related diseases by 2030?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the World Health Organization (WHO) has officially declared a global health emergency specifically due to the rise in diseases directly attributed to climate change. Such diseases may include, but are not limited to, vector-borne diseases, water-borne diseases, food safety and nutrition-related conditions, and respiratory and cardiovascular diseases linked to air pollution. In the absence of a direct announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) confirming the declaration will be sufficient for resolution. Q.title: Will machine learning algorithms surpass human accuracy in predicting consumer behavior by 2025?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, machine learning algorithms have been demonstrated to surpass human accuracy in predicting consumer behavior in at least one major industry (e.g., retail, finance, entertainment). The study or report must compare the predictive accuracy of machine learning algorithms against that of experienced human professionals in the same field, using standardized metrics for accuracy. The findings must be recognized and reported by at least two major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) or industry-specific publications. Machine learning algorithms are defined as systems that use statistical techniques to learn from data and make predictions or decisions without being explicitly programmed for the task.

P.title: Will the average global temperature increase by more than 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels before 2050?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2050, the global average temperature is confirmed to have increased by more than 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels (defined as the average global temperature from 1850-1900). The assessment must be based on the annual average global surface temperature data as reported by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) or another authoritative scientific body that is recognized by the scientific community. In the event that the IPCC or the designated authoritative body discontinues, merges, or is replaced, the most directly comparable successor organization will be used for the resolution. Should there be significant controversy or dispute within the scientific community regarding the accuracy or interpretation of the data, the question will resolve based on the consensus opinion of the scientific community as reflected in peer-reviewed scientific literature.

Q.title: Will a new infectious disease emerge with a global infection rate exceeding 1% before 2030?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, a new infectious disease emerges with a global infection rate exceeding 1% of the world's population. The infection rate must be confirmed by the World Health Organization (WHO) or the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). For the purpose of this question, a "new infectious disease" refers to a pathogen not previously identified in humans before the date of this question. The global infection rate is defined as the percentage of the world's population confirmed to be infected by the disease, as reported by the WHO or CDC. In the absence of direct reports from these organizations, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) will be considered sufficient. In the event of conflicting reports, the average of the reported rates from these sources will be used to determine the resolution. This question does not consider the severity of the disease or the death rate, focusing solely on the infection rate.

P.title: Will the US House of Representatives pass significant legislation to regulate artificial intelligence by 2030?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the US House of Representatives has passed legislation that significantly regulates artificial intelligence (AI) in any of the following areas: development, deployment, ethical use, privacy, security, or bias mitigation. 

Significant legislation is defined as a bill that introduces new regulations or substantially amends existing regulations on AI. The bill must be passed by the US House of Representatives and must not be solely symbolic; it must have practical implications for the regulation of AI. 

The passage of the legislation must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. 

In the event that multiple pieces of legislation are passed, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one meets the criteria outlined above.

Q.title: Will a biotechnology breakthrough lead to a significant increase in global GDP by 2030?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a biotechnology breakthrough is directly linked to a significant increase in global GDP. A "significant increase" is defined as a rise in global GDP by at least 5% over a baseline year, adjusted for inflation, attributable to biotechnological advancements. The breakthrough must be widely recognized by the global economic and scientific communities, with confirmation from at least three of the following organizations or publications: The World Bank, International Monetary Fund (IMF), Nature Biotechnology, or Science. The increase in GDP must be reported by reputable global financial news sources, such as Bloomberg, Financial Times, or The Economist. In the event of multiple contributing factors to GDP growth, the biotechnology breakthrough must be identified as the primary driver. This question does not consider incremental improvements in existing biotechnologies but focuses on a novel breakthrough that marks a significant departure from current capabilities.

P.title: Will a breakthrough in nuclear fusion technology be achieved by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a breakthrough in nuclear fusion technology is achieved and publicly announced. A "breakthrough" is defined as achieving a net energy gain from a nuclear fusion reaction that is sustainable and reproducible in a controlled environment. The breakthrough must be recognized and confirmed by at least one of the following: the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), the Department of Energy (DOE) of the United States, or a similar authoritative body in the field of nuclear energy. Additionally, the achievement must be documented in a peer-reviewed scientific journal or presented at a major scientific conference. In the absence of an official announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) are sufficient. The question will resolve as No if these conditions are not met by the specified date.

Q.title: Will the United States become the world's largest producer of renewable energy by 2030?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the United States is officially recognized as the world's largest producer of renewable energy, measured by total megawatts (MW) of renewable energy capacity installed or by total renewable energy generated in a year. Renewable energy includes solar, wind, hydroelectric, geothermal, and biomass energy sources. The assessment will be based on data and reports from authoritative sources such as the International Energy Agency (IEA), the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA), or equivalent. In the event of discrepancies between sources, the source with the most comprehensive and recent data will be considered authoritative. The resolution will consider only operational capacity, excluding projects under construction or in planning stages. In case of a tie or near-tie (within a 1% margin), the question will resolve as No, requiring clear leadership in renewable energy production.

P.title: Will Spain introduce a new policy to regulate the operation of electric vehicle companies like Tesla by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, Spain has officially introduced a new policy or set of regulations specifically aimed at governing the operation of electric vehicle (EV) companies, including but not limited to Tesla, within its jurisdiction. The policy must address at least one of the following areas: vehicle sales, charging infrastructure, environmental standards, or operational licensing for EV companies. The introduction of such a policy must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The policy must be enacted and in force, not merely proposed or under consideration. In the event of a regional policy (e.g., limited to specific autonomous communities or cities) that is intended for national adoption, the question will resolve as Yes. Policies that are part of broader EU directives but specifically implemented by Spain also count towards this question's resolution.

Q.title: Will the United Nations adopt a new global climate agreement before 2030?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, the United Nations officially adopts a new global climate agreement aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions, promoting sustainable development, or enhancing international cooperation on climate change. The agreement must be adopted by a majority of UN member states during a UN Climate Change Conference or a similar high-level meeting. The adoption of the agreement must be confirmed by an official UN announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The agreement must represent a new initiative or a significant amendment to existing agreements (e.g., the Paris Agreement) and must be intended for global implementation. Temporary measures or agreements limited to specific regions or groups of countries do not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will the widespread adoption of COVID-19 vaccines lead to a permanent change in workplace dynamics by 2030?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, there is a significant and permanent change in workplace dynamics directly attributable to the widespread adoption of COVID-19 vaccines. Significant change is defined as:
- A permanent increase of at least 20% in the number of employees working remotely or in hybrid models compared to pre-pandemic levels (2019).
- The implementation of permanent flexible working hours by at least 50% of Fortune 500 companies.
- The establishment of permanent health and safety protocols in the workplace, including but not limited to vaccination requirements, that were not standard prior to the pandemic.

Changes must be documented by credible sources, including but not limited to surveys by major human resources consultancies (e.g., Deloitte, PwC), reports from reputable news organizations (BBC, The New York Times, The Guardian), or official statements from companies. Temporary measures or changes solely due to government mandates that are lifted do not count towards this question's resolution.

Q.title: Will a major infectious disease outbreak lead to the implementation of new global health policies by 2025?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a major infectious disease outbreak has led to the implementation of new global health policies. A "major infectious disease outbreak" is defined as an event where a disease causes significant morbidity or mortality in at least three countries across different WHO regions, and is officially declared a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC) by the World Health Organization (WHO).

New global health policies must be adopted by at least five member countries of the United Nations and aim to address the prevention, preparedness, or response to infectious diseases. These policies must be documented in official government publications or announcements. In the absence of such documentation, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) will be considered sufficient evidence.

In the event that multiple outbreaks occur, the question will resolve as Yes if any one of them meets the criteria above.

P.title: Will France experience a major social movement leading to significant policy changes by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, France has experienced a major social movement that leads to significant policy changes. A "major social movement" is defined as a widespread mobilization of people across multiple cities, recognized by major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Le Monde, France24) and involving at least 100,000 participants in total. "Significant policy changes" refer to legislative or executive actions that alter national policy in at least one of the following areas: labor laws, environmental regulations, social welfare, or civil rights. The changes must be directly attributable to the social movement and recognized as such by at least two of the aforementioned news organizations. In the event of multiple movements, the question resolves as Yes if any one of them meets these criteria. Temporary or symbolic measures do not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will a major technology company face a landmark ethics investigation by the United States government before 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, a major technology company (defined as a company with a market capitalization exceeding $100 billion USD at the time of the investigation's announcement) faces a landmark ethics investigation by the United States government. A "landmark ethics investigation" is defined as an investigation that is publicly announced by a U.S. federal government agency, such as the Federal Trade Commission (FTC), the Department of Justice (DOJ), or the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), and involves allegations of significant ethical breaches that could potentially lead to regulatory changes, substantial fines, or major shifts in company policy. The investigation must be new and not a continuation or expansion of previously known issues. Confirmation of such an investigation must come from official government releases or credible news reports from reputable sources such as The New York Times, The Washington Post, Reuters, or Bloomberg. In the event of ambiguous situations, the resolution will default to a No unless clear evidence is presented.

Q.title: Will a major geopolitical event significantly impact global health security by 2025?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a major geopolitical event has significantly impacted global health security. A "major geopolitical event" is defined as an event that involves the military, political, or economic actions of one or more countries that have a widespread impact on global stability or international relations. The impact on "global health security" must be significant, affecting international health regulations, causing widespread health crises (e.g., pandemics, significant increases in mortality rates, or major disruptions to healthcare systems), or leading to substantial changes in global health policy. The event and its impact on global health security must be confirmed by at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) or official statements from international health organizations (WHO, CDC). In the absence of direct evidence, a consensus among experts in international relations and global health, as reported by the aforementioned sources, will be considered sufficient. The resolution will consider the direct and immediate effects of the geopolitical event, not long-term consequences that unfold over years.

P.title: Will a major technology company face a landmark ethics investigation by the United States government before 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, a major technology company (defined as a company with a market capitalization exceeding $100 billion USD at the time of the investigation's announcement) faces a landmark ethics investigation by the United States government. A "landmark ethics investigation" is defined as an investigation that is publicly announced by a U.S. federal government agency, such as the Federal Trade Commission (FTC), the Department of Justice (DOJ), or the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), and involves allegations of significant ethical breaches that could potentially lead to regulatory changes, substantial fines, or major shifts in company policy. The investigation must be new and not a continuation or expansion of previously known issues. Confirmation of such an investigation must come from official government releases or credible news reports from reputable sources such as The New York Times, The Washington Post, Reuters, or Bloomberg. In the event of ambiguous situations, the resolution will default to a No unless clear evidence is presented.

Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, machine learning algorithms have been demonstrated to surpass human accuracy in predicting consumer behavior in at least one major industry (e.g., retail, finance, entertainment). The surpassing of human accuracy must be evidenced by a peer-reviewed study or a comprehensive report from a reputable analytics or research firm. The study or report must compare the predictive accuracy of machine learning algorithms against that of experienced human professionals in the same field, using standardized metrics for accuracy. The findings must be recognized and reported by at least two major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) or industry-specific publications. In the event of conflicting reports or studies, the question will resolve based on the consensus of the most reputable sources. Machine learning algorithms are defined as systems that use statistical techniques to learn from data and make predictions or decisions without being explicitly programmed for the task.

P.title: Will advancements in microbiology influence global health policies more than technology by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, advancements in microbiology have had a more significant influence on global health policies than technological advancements. Technological advancements include, but are not limited to, developments in medical devices, health information technologies, and biotechnology. Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by January 1, 2025, the Democratic Party has secured a majority of seats in both the House of Representatives and the Senate following the 2024 United States general elections. A majority in the Senate is defined as holding more than half of the total seats, which currently stands at 51 out of 100, or 50 seats plus the Vice President's tie-breaking vote if the Vice President is a Democrat. P.title: Will a biotechnology breakthrough lead to a significant increase in global GDP by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a biotechnology breakthrough is directly linked to a significant increase in global GDP. A "significant increase" is defined as a rise in global GDP by at least 5% over a baseline year, adjusted for inflation, attributable to biotechnological advancements. The breakthrough must be widely recognized by the global economic and scientific communities, with confirmation from at least three of the following organizations or publications: The World Bank, International Monetary Fund (IMF), Nature Biotechnology, or Science. The increase in GDP must be reported by reputable global financial news sources, such as Bloomberg, Financial Times, or The Economist. In the event of multiple contributing factors to GDP growth, the biotechnology breakthrough must be identified as the primary driver. This question does not consider incremental improvements in existing biotechnologies but focuses on a novel breakthrough that marks a significant departure from current capabilities.

Q.title: Will there be a significant discovery in robotics that contributes to the advancement of natural sciences by 2030?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a significant discovery in robotics has been made that contributes to the advancement of the natural sciences. A "significant discovery" is defined as a development in robotics technology or application that leads to a breakthrough in understanding, methodology, or application in any field of the natural sciences (e.g., biology, chemistry, physics, earth science). The discovery must be recognized as significant by the scientific community, evidenced by publication in a peer-reviewed scientific journal, citation in multiple subsequent research works, or acknowledgment by a reputable scientific organization. The advancement must be directly attributable to the robotics discovery and represent a clear departure from existing capabilities or knowledge. In the event of multiple discoveries, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one meets these criteria. Discoveries that are primarily advancements in computer science or engineering without direct application to the natural sciences do not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will a breakthrough in physics lead to a new form of clean energy by 2040?
P.body:

- The breakthrough must be documented in at least one peer-reviewed scientific journal and recognized by a reputable scientific organization or consensus within the scientific community.
- The new energy source must be proven to be scalable for widespread use and demonstrate a significant advantage over existing clean energy sources in terms of efficiency, cost, or environmental impact.
- The development of the new energy source must be confirmed by an official announcement from a leading research institution or a major energy company.

In the absence of an official announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The energy source must be operational, not merely theoretical or in a prototype phase, by the resolution date.

P.title: Will a machine learning model surpass human accuracy in diagnosing diseases by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a machine learning model is officially recognized to surpass human accuracy in diagnosing diseases. The model must demonstrate superior accuracy across multiple diseases in a peer-reviewed study or studies, compared to the consensus accuracy rates of medical professionals in those domains. The study or studies must be published in a reputable medical journal and the findings must be validated by at least one independent research institution or a recognized medical authority. The model's performance must be evaluated in real-world conditions, not solely in controlled or laboratory settings. In the event of multiple models achieving this milestone, the question will resolve as Yes upon the first such recognition. The resolution will rely on reports from authoritative sources in the medical and scientific community, including but not limited to the World Health Organization, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and major medical journals.

Q.title: Will the United Nations establish a global AI ethics framework by 2030?

It must be adopted by the UN through an official act, such as a resolution passed by the General Assembly or an agreement among member states. The establishment of the framework must be confirmed by an official UN announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The framework must include specific guidelines or principles addressing ethical considerations related to AI, such as transparency, accountability, privacy, and fairness. In the event of a partial or preliminary framework, the question will resolve as Yes only if there is a clear commitment and timeline for the adoption of a comprehensive global framework.

P.title: Will a major epidemic influence the outcome of a national election in any country before 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, a major epidemic significantly influences the outcome of a national election in any country. A "major epidemic" is defined as an outbreak of disease that results in significant morbidity or mortality, receives widespread national or international media coverage, and is officially declared an epidemic by the World Health Organization (WHO) or the national health authority of the country in question. The influence on the election outcome must be clearly attributable to the epidemic, such as through a significant shift in public opinion, voter turnout, or the implementation of election-related policies (e.g., mail-in voting, election postponement). The determination of significant influence will be based on analysis from at least three reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) or academic publications. In the event of multiple epidemics influencing elections in different countries, the question will resolve as Yes upon the first verified instance.

P.title: Will the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention publish a comprehensive report on the health impacts of climate change by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has published a comprehensive report on the health impacts of climate change. The report must cover a wide range of health impacts directly and indirectly related to climate change, including but not limited to: - Changes in the distribution and prevalence of vector-borne diseases; - Impacts on mental health and well-being; - Effects on air quality and respiratory health; - The influence of extreme weather events on public health. The report must be publicly accessible and recognized by the CDC as comprehensive in its coverage of climate change's health impacts. In the absence of a single comprehensive report, a series of publications by the CDC that collectively cover the criteria above will also satisfy the resolution criteria. The resolution will rely on official CDC announcements or publications. In the event that the CDC has not published such a report by the specified date, the question will resolve as No.

P.title: Will the United States become the world's largest producer of renewable energy by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the United States is officially recognized as the world's largest producer of renewable energy, measured by total megawatts (MW) of renewable energy capacity installed or by total renewable energy generated in a year. Renewable energy includes solar, wind, hydroelectric, geothermal, and biomass energy sources. The assessment will be based on data and reports from authoritative sources such as the International Energy Agency (IEA), the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA), or equivalent. In the event of discrepancies between sources, the source with the most comprehensive and recent data will be considered authoritative. The resolution will consider only operational capacity, excluding projects under construction or in planning stages. In case of a tie or near-tie (within a 1% margin), the question will resolve as No, requiring clear leadership in renewable energy production.

Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a significant scientific discovery is made that directly influences United States environmental policy. The discovery must be related to environmental science and must be recognized as significant by the scientific community, as evidenced by publication in a peer-reviewed scientific journal or endorsement by a major scientific organization. The influence on policy must be clearly attributable to the discovery, as confirmed by official government documentation or statements from relevant policymakers. P.title: Will India implement a nationwide policy to significantly reduce air pollution levels by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, India has officially implemented a nationwide policy aimed at significantly reducing air pollution levels. The policy must demonstrate a clear, measurable goal for reduction in major pollutants (e.g., PM2.5, PM10, NOx, SO2) compared to 2020 levels. Significant reduction is defined as a decrease of at least 20% in the annual average concentration of these pollutants across major cities in India. The implementation of the policy must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The policy must be in effect, not merely proposed or in a planning stage. In the event of regional policies that collectively cover the entire nation, the question will resolve as Yes if these policies meet the overall reduction goal.

Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, there is a significant shift in environmental philosophy that influences global climate policy. P.title: Will a major discovery in epidemiology lead to a significant shift in global health policy by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a major discovery in the field of epidemiology leads to a significant shift in global health policy. A "major discovery" is defined as a finding that substantially alters the understanding of disease transmission, prevention, or treatment, and is recognized as such by the World Health Organization (WHO) or a similar authoritative body in the field of public health. A "significant shift" in global health policy refers to the adoption of new guidelines, practices, or strategies by at least three G20 countries, as a direct result of the discovery, that markedly change the approach to disease prevention, management, or containment. The shift must be documented by official government announcements, policy documents, or credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). Discoveries that only lead to minor adjustments or are limited to national or regional significance do not meet this criterion. The resolution will consider only those changes that are implemented and publicly acknowledged by the respective governments or organizations by the resolution date.

P.title: Will a new infectious disease emerge with a global infection rate exceeding 1% before 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, a new infectious disease emerges with a global infection rate exceeding 1% of the world's population. The infection rate must be confirmed by the World Health Organization (WHO) or the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). For the purpose of this question, a "new infectious disease" refers to a pathogen not previously identified in humans before the date of this question. The global infection rate is defined as the percentage of the world's population confirmed to be infected by the disease, as reported by the WHO or CDC. In the absence of direct reports from these organizations, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) will be considered sufficient. In the event of conflicting reports, the average of the reported rates from these sources will be used to determine the resolution. This question does not consider the severity of the disease or the death rate, focusing solely on the infection rate.

P.title: Will a significant international climate change treaty be ratified by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a significant international climate change treaty is ratified. A "significant" treaty is defined as one that includes commitments from at least 75% of the world's nations and aims to reduce global greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40% from 1990 levels by 2050. The treaty must be ratified by the participating countries' governments or relevant governing bodies. Ratification is confirmed through official government announcements or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The treaty must be new, not an amendment or extension of an existing treaty. In the event of multiple treaties, the question resolves as Yes if at least one meets these criteria.

P.title: Will a machine learning model be used to predict significant natural disasters with over 90% accuracy by 2030?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a machine learning model is used to predict significant natural disasters (including but not limited to earthquakes, hurricanes, tsunamis, and volcanic eruptions) with over 90% accuracy. 

Significant natural disasters are defined as events causing substantial damage, significant economic loss, or loss of life. The model must predict the location, time frame (within a 48-hour window), and magnitude of the event with over 90% accuracy, verified by subsequent events. 

The prediction model must be recognized and validated by a reputable scientific or governmental organization involved in disaster management or research. 

In the absence of official validation, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the use and accuracy of the model are sufficient. 

The model must be operational and used in a real-world scenario, not solely within a research or trial setting.

Q.title: Will machine learning algorithms surpass human accuracy in image recognition by 2025?
Q.body:

P.title: Will advancements in string theory lead to a breakthrough in nuclear fusion technology by 2040?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2040, advancements in string theory have directly contributed to a significant breakthrough in nuclear fusion technology. A "significant breakthrough" is defined as a development that enables a nuclear fusion reactor to achieve and maintain net positive energy output for at least 24 continuous hours. The breakthrough must be attributable to theoretical or practical applications of string theory, as confirmed by publication in a peer-reviewed scientific journal or an official announcement from a leading nuclear fusion research institution (e.g., ITER, National Ignition Facility, or similar). In the absence of direct evidence linking the breakthrough to string theory, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The breakthrough must represent a substantial improvement over current capabilities and not merely an incremental advancement.

P.title: Will a major discovery in epidemiology lead to a significant shift in global health policy by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a major discovery in the field of epidemiology leads to a significant shift in global health policy. A "major discovery" is defined as a finding that substantially alters the understanding of disease transmission, prevention, or treatment, and is recognized as such by the World Health Organization (WHO) or a similar authoritative body in the field of public health. A "significant shift" in global health policy refers to the adoption of new guidelines, practices, or strategies by at least three G20 countries, as a direct result of the discovery, that markedly change the approach to disease prevention, management, or containment. The shift must be documented by official government announcements, policy documents, or credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). Discoveries that only lead to minor adjustments or are limited to national or regional significance do not meet this criterion. The resolution will consider only those changes that are implemented and publicly acknowledged by the respective governments or organizations by the resolution date.

Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a major geopolitical event has significantly impacted global health security. A "major geopolitical event" is defined as an event that involves the military, political, or economic actions of one or more countries that have a widespread impact on global stability or international relations. The impact on "global health security" must be significant, affecting international health regulations, causing widespread health crises (e.g., pandemics, significant increases in mortality rates, or major disruptions to healthcare systems), or leading to substantial changes in global health policy. The event and its impact on global health security must be confirmed by at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) or official statements from international health organizations (WHO, CDC). In the absence of direct evidence, a consensus among experts in international relations and global health, as reported by the aforementioned sources, will be considered sufficient. The resolution will consider the direct and immediate effects of the geopolitical event, not long-term consequences that unfold over years.

A "major shift" in global climate policy is defined as the adoption of new, substantial climate policies or amendments to existing policies by at least three of the following entities: the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), the European Union, the United States, China, and India. These policies must represent a significant departure from current strategies and aim to substantially reduce greenhouse gas emissions or enhance climate resilience. The shift must be confirmed by official documentation from the relevant entities or credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters).

A "major breakthrough" is defined as a discovery or development that results in a measurable and significant improvement in crop resilience against factors such as drought, temperature extremes, salinity, and pests, compared to the state of the art as of 2023. The increase in resilience must be demonstrated through peer-reviewed scientific research, recognized by the global scientific community, and must show practical application in at least three different major crops (e.g., rice, wheat, maize). In the absence of direct recognition, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a new infectious disease emerges that leads to a global pandemic with a mortality rate exceeding that of COVID-19 as reported by the World Health Organization (WHO). For the purpose of this question, "global pandemic" is defined as an outbreak of a disease that occurs over a wide geographic area and affects an exceptionally high proportion of the global population. The emergence of the disease must be confirmed by the WHO, and its global impact must be reported by at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). In the event that the WHO is dissolved or rendered inactive, a consensus of at least three leading health organizations (e.g., CDC, ECDC, China CDC) will be required for resolution. The question will resolve as No if no such disease emerges by the specified date.

P.title: Will a machine learning model be used to predict significant natural disasters with over 90% accuracy by 2030?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a machine learning model is used to predict significant natural disasters (including but not limited to earthquakes, hurricanes, tsunamis, and volcanic eruptions) with over 90% accuracy. 

Significant natural disasters are defined as events causing substantial damage, significant economic loss, or loss of life. The model must predict the location, time frame (within a 48-hour window), and magnitude of the event with over 90% accuracy, verified by subsequent events. 

The prediction model must be recognized and validated by a reputable scientific or governmental organization involved in disaster management or research. 

In the absence of official validation, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the use and accuracy of the model are sufficient. 

The model must be operational and used in a real-world scenario, not solely within a research or trial setting.

P.title: Will a machine learning model be used to predict significant natural disasters with over 90% accuracy by 2030?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a machine learning model is used to predict significant natural disasters (including but not limited to earthquakes, hurricanes, tsunamis, and volcanic eruptions) with over 90% accuracy. 

Significant natural disasters are defined as events causing substantial damage, significant economic loss, or loss of life. The model must predict the location, time frame (within a 48-hour window), and magnitude of the event with over 90% accuracy, verified by subsequent events. 

The prediction model must be recognized and validated by a reputable scientific or governmental organization involved in disaster management or research. 

In the absence of official validation, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the use and accuracy of the model are sufficient.

The development must be confirmed by an official announcement from a recognized government body, research institution, or corporation involved in nuclear technology or biocontainment. P.title: Will a member of the United Nations introduce a resolution to regulate artificial intelligence globally by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, any member country of the United Nations has officially introduced a resolution aimed at regulating artificial intelligence (AI) on a global scale. The introduction of such a resolution must be confirmed by an official UN document or announcement. In the absence of direct UN confirmation, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) will be considered sufficient evidence. Q.title: Will a new global pandemic treaty be established by the WHO with unanimous support from all member countries by 2025?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the World Health Organization (WHO) has established a new global pandemic treaty that has received unanimous support from all member countries. 

For the purposes of this question, a "global pandemic treaty" refers to a formal, legally binding agreement between WHO member countries aimed at preventing, preparing for, and responding to future pandemics. Unanimous support means that all member countries of the WHO at the time of the treaty's establishment have formally agreed to the treaty's terms without exception. 

Confirmation must come from an official WHO announcement or documentation. In the absence of an official announcement, confirmation from at least three reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) will be considered sufficient. 

In the event that the WHO gains new members after the establishment of the treaty but before the resolution date, the treaty must have been agreed upon by all members present at the time of establishment for this question to resolve as Yes.

P.title: Will India become a global leader in quantum computing by 2030?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, India is recognized as a global leader in the field of quantum computing. Recognition as a global leader requires:
- India hosting at least one quantum computer that ranks among the top 5 in the world for computational power, as reported by a reputable global technology or scientific organization.
- Indian-based researchers or institutions publishing at least 20 significant, peer-reviewed research papers on quantum computing in top-tier scientific journals.
- India successfully commercializing quantum computing technologies, with at least one Indian company being among the top 5 globally in terms of market share or technological innovation in quantum computing.

Recognition must come from authoritative sources in the field of quantum computing, such as the IEEE, the International Quantum Computing Institute, or similar. Reports from major global technology news outlets (e.g., Wired, TechCrunch, Bloomberg Technology) can also contribute to this recognition. In the absence of clear global leadership, the question will resolve as No.

Q.title: Will China implement a comprehensive legal framework for regulating artificial intelligence by 2025?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, China has officially implemented a comprehensive legal framework for the regulation of artificial intelligence (AI). The framework must cover at least the following areas: 
- Ethical use of AI
- Data privacy and protection
- AI in public surveillance
- Autonomous vehicles
- AI in healthcare
The implementation of such a framework must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. 
For the purpose of this question, a "comprehensive legal framework" is defined as a set of laws or regulations that collectively address the ethical, social, economic, and technical aspects of AI deployment and use across multiple sectors. 
In the event of partial implementation (e.g., regulations covering only certain sectors), the question will resolve as No unless the missing sectors are explicitly stated to be covered in a subsequent phase of implementation.

P.title: Will a major election in a democratic country be significantly influenced by a sudden atmospheric event before 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, a major election in a democratic country is significantly influenced by a sudden atmospheric event. A "major election" is defined as a presidential, parliamentary, or general election in a country recognized as a democracy by the Economist Intelligence Unit's Democracy Index. A "sudden atmospheric event" includes but is not limited to hurricanes, tornadoes, blizzards, heatwaves, and significant air pollution events. The influence on the election must be substantial, leading to a significant change in the election date, voting process, or outcome. The event and its impact on the election must be confirmed by at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). In the event of multiple atmospheric events influencing elections in different countries, the question will resolve as Yes upon the first confirmed instance. Edge cases will be considered on a case-by-case basis, with a focus on the intent of the question and the significance of the atmospheric event's impact on the election process or outcome.

Q.title: Will the Supreme Court of the US make a landmark ruling that significantly affects the outcome of a presidential election before 2030?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, the Supreme Court of the United States issues a ruling that directly influences the outcome of a presidential election. A ruling is considered to have a significant effect if it alters the result of an election or has a decisive impact on the electoral process in a manner that could change the outcome. This includes, but is not limited to, decisions on electoral disputes, voting rights, candidate eligibility, or election procedures. The ruling must be reported by at least three reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, The Washington Post, The Guardian). In the event of multiple rulings, the question will resolve as Yes upon the first ruling that meets these criteria. In cases where the impact of a ruling is disputed, this question will resolve based on the consensus of legal analysts in major legal publications or news outlets.

P.title: Will a breakthrough in aerospace engineering lead to a significant improvement in global pandemic response capabilities by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a breakthrough in aerospace engineering has led to a significant improvement in global pandemic response capabilities. A "significant improvement" is defined as a development that enables at least a 30% reduction in global pandemic response time or a 20% increase in the distribution efficiency of medical supplies, vaccines, or personnel compared to 2023 standards. The breakthrough must be in the field of aerospace engineering and directly contribute to the improvement of pandemic response capabilities. This includes, but is not limited to, innovations in aircraft design, logistics, and transportation technologies that enhance the speed, efficiency, or reach of pandemic response efforts. The improvement must be documented and recognized by at least one of the following: the World Health Organization (WHO), the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), or a similar authoritative public health body. In the absence of official recognition, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. Temporary or experimental deployments do not count towards this question's resolution.

Q.title: Will a new infectious disease outbreak before 2025 lead to a global economic downturn?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, a new infectious disease outbreak is identified and leads to a global economic downturn. A "new infectious disease outbreak" refers to the emergence of a disease not previously identified in humans, causing widespread illness. A "global economic downturn" is defined as a decline in global GDP by at least 0.5% over a calendar year, as reported by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) or the World Bank. The outbreak must be confirmed by the World Health Organization (WHO) or the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). In the event of conflicting reports, the question will resolve based on the consensus of these two organizations. The economic impact must be directly attributed to the outbreak by the IMF, the World Bank, or a consensus of economic analysts in reputable financial news sources (e.g., Financial Times, Bloomberg, Reuters).

P.title: Will the United Nations adopt a new global climate agreement before 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, the United Nations officially adopts a new global climate agreement aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions, promoting sustainable development, or enhancing international cooperation on climate change. The adoption of the agreement must be confirmed by an official UN announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The agreement must represent a new initiative or a significant amendment to existing agreements (e.g., the Paris Agreement) and must be intended for global implementation. Temporary measures or agreements limited to specific regions or groups of countries do not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will a major geopolitical event significantly impact global health security by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a major geopolitical event has significantly impacted global health security. A "major geopolitical event" is defined as an event that involves the military, political, or economic actions of one or more countries that have a widespread impact on global stability or international relations. The impact on "global health security" must be significant, affecting international health regulations, causing widespread health crises (e.g., pandemics, significant increases in mortality rates, or major disruptions to healthcare systems), or leading to substantial changes in global health policy. The event and its impact on global health security must be confirmed by at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) or official statements from international health organizations (WHO, CDC). In the absence of direct evidence, a consensus among experts in international relations and global health, as reported by the aforementioned sources, will be considered sufficient. The resolution will consider the direct and immediate effects of the geopolitical event, not long-term consequences that unfold over years.

P.title: Will a biotechnology breakthrough lead to a significant increase in global GDP by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a biotechnology breakthrough is directly linked to a significant increase in global GDP. A "significant increase" is defined as a rise in global GDP by at least 5% over a baseline year, adjusted for inflation, attributable to biotechnological advancements. The breakthrough must be widely recognized by the global economic and scientific communities, with confirmation from at least three of the following organizations or publications: The World Bank, International Monetary Fund (IMF), Nature Biotechnology, or Science. The increase in GDP must be reported by reputable global financial news sources, such as Bloomberg, Financial Times, or The Economist. In the event of multiple contributing factors to GDP growth, the biotechnology breakthrough must be identified as the primary driver. This question does not consider incremental improvements in existing biotechnologies but focuses on a novel breakthrough that marks a significant departure from current capabilities.

Q.title: Will there be a significant increase in global health funding due to climate-related diseases by 2025?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, there is a significant increase in global health funding specifically allocated to address climate-related diseases. A "significant increase" is defined as a rise of at least 25% in total funding compared to the year 2020, adjusted for inflation. Climate-related diseases include, but are not limited to, vector-borne diseases, heat-related illnesses, and water-borne diseases. The increase in funding must be confirmed by official reports or statements from major global health organizations such as the World Health Organization (WHO), the United Nations (UN), or the World Bank. In the absence of direct statements, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) will be considered sufficient. The funding increase must be specifically earmarked for research, prevention, and treatment of climate-related diseases. General increases in health funding without explicit allocation to climate-related diseases do not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will machine learning be used to predict election outcomes in any country with over 90% accuracy before 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, a machine learning model is used to predict the outcome of a national election in any country with a population exceeding 1 million people, and achieves an accuracy rate of over 90% compared to the official election results. P.title: Will France implement a nationwide carbon neutrality policy by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, France has officially implemented a nationwide policy aimed at achieving carbon neutrality. The policy must encompass measures to significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions across all sectors of the economy, including but not limited to energy, transportation, agriculture, and industry, with the goal of balancing emitted and absorbed greenhouse gases. Implementation is defined as the policy being enacted into law by the French government, with clear, actionable steps and timelines for achieving carbon neutrality. Confirmation must come from official government announcements or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. In the event of a partial implementation (e.g., limited to specific regions or sectors), the question will resolve as Yes only if there is a clear, government-confirmed plan for nationwide application.

Q.title: Will there be a major nuclear accident reported in the news by 2030?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a major nuclear accident is reported by at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters). A "major nuclear accident" is defined as an event classified at Level 5 or above on the International Nuclear Event Scale (INES), indicating wider consequences beyond the immediate site of the incident. The accident must be confirmed by official sources or through detailed reporting by the aforementioned news organizations. In the event of conflicting reports about the severity of the incident, the question will resolve based on the consensus of coverage by the specified news organizations. Temporary safety incidents or events classified below Level 5 on the INES do not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will a new infectious disease outbreak before 2025 lead to a global economic downturn?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, a new infectious disease outbreak is identified and leads to a global economic downturn. A "new infectious disease outbreak" refers to the emergence of a disease not previously identified in humans, causing widespread illness. A "global economic downturn" is defined as a decline in global GDP by at least 0.5% over a calendar year, as reported by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) or the World Bank.
