P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, a new infectious disease outbreak is identified and leads to a global economic downturn. A "new infectious disease outbreak" refers to the emergence of a disease not previously identified in humans, causing widespread illness. A "global economic downturn" is defined as a decline in global GDP by at least 0.5% over a calendar year, as reported by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) or the World Bank. The outbreak must be confirmed by the World Health Organization (WHO) or the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). In the event of conflicting reports, the question will resolve based on the consensus of these two organizations. The economic impact must be directly attributed to the outbreak by the IMF, the World Bank, or a consensus of economic analysts in reputable financial news sources (e.g., Financial Times, Bloomberg, Reuters).

Q.title: Will a major breakthrough in pharmacology be announced that significantly extends human lifespan by 2030?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a major breakthrough in pharmacology is announced that significantly extends human lifespan. A "major breakthrough" is defined as a pharmacological discovery or development that is scientifically proven to extend the average human lifespan by at least 10 years. The breakthrough must be documented in at least one of the following: 
- A publication in a peer-reviewed scientific journal of high impact. 
- An official announcement from a leading health organization (e.g., World Health Organization, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, National Institutes of Health). 
For the purpose of this question, "significantly extends human lifespan" refers to the extension of life expectancy at birth. The announcement must be supported by clinical trial results that demonstrate the efficacy of the pharmacological intervention in humans. In the absence of such an announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. 
In the event of multiple announcements, the question will resolve based on the first announcement that meets these criteria.

reasons: A new infectious disease outbreak leading to a global economic downturn could potentially accelerate research and funding in the field of pharmacology, including efforts to extend human lifespan. The urgency to address health crises might lead to more breakthroughs.
Economic downturns often lead to increased government and private sector investment in healthcare and pharmaceutical research as a means to stimulate the economy and address public health concerns.

The psychological and social impacts of a global economic downturn caused by a new infectious disease outbreak might increase public and scientific interest in breakthroughs that promise significant health benefits, including lifespan extension.
relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, as the occurrence of one event could influence the likelihood or timing of the other.

verification_result.reasoning: R is a logical disjunction of P and Q because it will resolve as Yes if either P or Q is true. P is about a new infectious disease outbreak leading to a global economic downturn before 2025, and Q is about a major breakthrough in pharmacology significantly extending human lifespan by 2030. R encompasses both scenarios, stating that it will resolve as Yes if either of these events occurs.

P.title: Will the Food and Drug Administration's new policies significantly influence the outcome of the next US presidential election?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by January 1 following the next US presidential election, there is clear evidence that the Food and Drug Administration's (FDA) new policies have significantly influenced the outcome of the presidential election. Significant influence is defined as a measurable impact on voter behavior, election results, or public opinion, directly attributable to the FDA's policies. This impact must be confirmed by at least three reputable sources (e.g., major news organizations like BBC, The New York Times, Washington Post, or academic studies). In the absence of direct evidence, a consensus among political analysts from at least three major news organizations or academic institutions that the FDA's policies played a critical role in the election outcome will also result in a Yes resolution. The resolution will consider only policies introduced before the election year.

Q.title: Will the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention publish a comprehensive report on the health impacts of climate change by 2025?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has published a comprehensive report on the health impacts of climate change. The report must cover a wide range of health impacts directly and indirectly related to climate change, including but not limited to: - Changes in the distribution and prevalence of vector-borne diseases; - Impacts on mental health and well-being; - Effects on air quality and respiratory health; - The influence of extreme weather events on public health. The report must be publicly accessible and recognized by the CDC as comprehensive in its coverage of climate change's health impacts. In the absence of a single comprehensive report, a series of publications by the CDC that collectively cover the criteria above will also satisfy the resolution criteria. The resolution will rely on official CDC announcements or publications. In the event that the CDC has not published such a report by the specified date, the question will resolve as No.

P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2024, a major political figure has officially proposed a global summit focused on virology research funding. A "major political figure" is defined as a current head of state, head of government, or a minister of health from any of the G20 nations. The proposal must be for a summit specifically aimed at discussing, planning, or increasing funding for virology research on a global scale. The proposal must be publicly documented through an official government press release, announcement, or in statements made during official government proceedings. In the absence of direct government documentation, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) will be considered sufficient. The summit does not need to take place by the resolution date; only the proposal is necessary for the question to resolve as Yes.

Q.title: Will a major election in a democratic country be significantly influenced by a sudden atmospheric event before 2030?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, a major election in a democratic country is significantly influenced by a sudden atmospheric event. A "major election" is defined as a presidential, parliamentary, or general election in a country recognized as a democracy by the Economist Intelligence Unit's Democracy Index. A "sudden atmospheric event" includes but is not limited to hurricanes, tornadoes, blizzards, heatwaves, and significant air pollution events. The influence on the election must be substantial, leading to a significant change in the election date, voting process, or outcome. The event and its impact on the election must be confirmed by at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). In the event of multiple atmospheric events influencing elections in different countries, the question will resolve as Yes upon the first confirmed instance. Edge cases will be considered on a case-by-case basis, with a focus on the intent of the question and the significance of the atmospheric event's impact on the election process or outcome.

P.title: Will there be a major nuclear accident reported in the news by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a major nuclear accident is reported by at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters). A "major nuclear accident" is defined as an event classified at Level 5 or above on the International Nuclear Event Scale (INES), indicating wider consequences beyond the immediate site of the incident. The accident must be confirmed by official sources or through detailed reporting by the aforementioned news organizations. In the event of conflicting reports about the severity of the incident, the question will resolve based on the consensus of coverage by the specified news organizations. Temporary safety incidents or events classified below Level 5 on the INES do not count towards this question's resolution.

Q.title: Will a major geopolitical event significantly impact international soccer tournaments by 2025?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a major geopolitical event has significantly impacted the scheduling, location, participation, or overall execution of international soccer tournaments.

A "major geopolitical event" is defined as an event that involves the government or military actions of one or more countries, leading to widespread international reactions or sanctions. Examples include, but are not limited to, wars, significant diplomatic disputes, economic sanctions, or major political changes.

The impact on soccer tournaments must be confirmed by FIFA or UEFA through official announcements or documentation. In the absence of such announcements, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient.

The question will resolve as No if no such events or impacts are confirmed by the resolution date.

P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, a decision by the Supreme Court of the United States directly results in a significant shift in the priorities of social sciences research in the United States. A "significant shift" is defined as a change in funding allocation by major research institutions or government bodies (e.g., National Science Foundation, National Institutes of Health) of at least 20% towards new or different areas of research within the social sciences, compared to the previous year. The shift must be attributable directly to the Supreme Court decision, as reported by at least three reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, The Washington Post) or official government announcements. The decision and its impact on research priorities must be clearly documented and recognized by the academic community in the social sciences.

Q.title: Will California introduce groundbreaking legislation on digital privacy by 2025?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, California has officially introduced legislation that is recognized as groundbreaking in the field of digital privacy. Groundbreaking legislation is defined as laws that significantly enhance the protection of digital privacy rights beyond the current standards as of 2023, or introduce new rights or mechanisms for the protection of digital data that are not present in existing California law or federal law. The legislation must be passed by the California State Legislature and signed into law by the Governor. Confirmation of such legislation must come from official government announcements or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) are sufficient. Proposed but not enacted legislation, or minor amendments to existing laws, do not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will a significant international climate change treaty be ratified by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a significant international climate change treaty is ratified. A "significant" treaty is defined as one that includes commitments from at least 75% of the world's nations and aims to reduce global greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40% from 1990 levels by 2050. The treaty must be ratified by the participating countries' governments or relevant governing bodies. Ratification is confirmed through official government announcements or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The treaty must be new, not an amendment or extension of an existing treaty. In the event of multiple treaties, the question resolves as Yes if at least one meets these criteria.

A "major epidemic" is defined as an outbreak of disease that results in significant morbidity or mortality, receives widespread national or international media coverage, and is officially declared an epidemic by the World Health Organization (WHO) or the national health authority of the country in question. The influence on the election outcome must be clearly attributable to the epidemic, such as through a significant shift in public opinion, voter turnout, or the implementation of election-related policies (e.g., mail-in voting, election postponement). The determination of significant influence will be based on analysis from at least three reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) or academic publications. In the event of multiple epidemics influencing elections in different countries, the question will resolve as Yes upon the first verified instance.

reasons: A significant international climate change treaty could potentially influence global health policies and preparedness, which might affect how countries respond to epidemics.
The political climate and international cooperation fostered by a climate change treaty might impact how countries handle public health crises, including epidemics.
A major epidemic influencing an election could shift political priorities towards health and environmental policies, potentially making the ratification of a climate change treaty more likely.
relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, as both involve significant global events that could influence each other.

verification_result.reasoning: R is the logical disjunction of P and Q because R will resolve as Yes if either P or Q resolves as Yes. Specifically, R will resolve as Yes if either a significant international climate change treaty is ratified by 2030 (P) or a major epidemic influences the outcome of a national election in any country before 2030 (Q).

P.title: Will the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention publish a comprehensive report on the health impacts of climate change by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has published a comprehensive report on the health impacts of climate change. The report must cover a wide range of health impacts directly and indirectly related to climate change, including but not limited to: - Changes in the distribution and prevalence of vector-borne diseases; - Impacts on mental health and well-being; - Effects on air quality and respiratory health; - The influence of extreme weather events on public health. The report must be publicly accessible and recognized by the CDC as comprehensive in its coverage of climate change's health impacts. In the absence of a single comprehensive report, a series of publications by the CDC that collectively cover the criteria above will also satisfy the resolution criteria. The resolution will rely on official CDC announcements or publications. In the event that the CDC has not published such a report by the specified date, the question will resolve as No.

Q.title: Will a major breakthrough in genetics lead to a significant increase in crop resilience to climate change by 2030?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a major breakthrough in genetics leads to a significant increase in crop resilience to climate change. A "major breakthrough" is defined as a discovery or development that results in a measurable and significant improvement in crop resilience against factors such as drought, temperature extremes, salinity, and pests, compared to the state of the art as of 2023.

The increase in resilience must be demonstrated through peer-reviewed scientific research, recognized by the global scientific community, and must show practical application in at least three different major crops (e.g., rice, wheat, maize).

The breakthrough must be widely recognized by authoritative bodies in the field of agricultural science or genetics, such as the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) or the International Society for Plant Pathology. In the absence of direct recognition, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient.

In the event of multiple discoveries, the question will resolve as Yes if any one discovery meets the above criteria.

P.title: Will biotechnology significantly enhance athlete performance in any major sports league by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, any major sports league (e.g., NBA, FIFA, NFL, MLB, NHL) officially recognizes the use of biotechnology as a significant factor in enhancing athlete performance. Significant enhancement includes, but is not limited to, increased physical endurance, strength, recovery speed, or agility, as confirmed by scientific studies or statistical evidence. The recognition must come from the league's governing body or an official statement from the league. In the absence of official recognition, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, ESPN) confirming the widespread use of biotechnology for performance enhancement in the league will suffice. Temporary or experimental use in minor leagues or individual teams does not count towards this question's resolution.

Q.title: Will Google announce a significant breakthrough in natural sciences research by 2025?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, Google (or any of its subsidiaries) officially announces a significant breakthrough in the field of natural sciences. A "significant breakthrough" is defined as a discovery or development that represents a major advancement in understanding or application in any of the natural sciences (including, but not limited to, biology, chemistry, physics, earth science, and astronomy). The announcement must be made through an official Google press release or a publication in a reputable scientific journal. The breakthrough must be recognized as significant by the scientific community, as evidenced by coverage in at least three major science news outlets (e.g., Scientific American, Nature News, Science Daily) or citations in peer-reviewed scientific journals. In the absence of widespread recognition, the question will resolve as No. The breakthrough must be new, not a continuation or incremental improvement of existing technologies or research.

P.title: Will France implement a nationwide carbon-neutral initiative by 2030?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, France has officially implemented a nationwide initiative that is recognized as carbon-neutral. The initiative must encompass actions across multiple sectors, including but not limited to energy, transportation, industry, and agriculture, aimed at achieving a net-zero carbon footprint for the country.

The initiative must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient.

For the purpose of this question, "carbon-neutral" means that any carbon emissions produced by France are balanced by an equivalent amount of carbon sequestration or offsetting measures, within the same calendar year. The verification of carbon neutrality must be conducted by an independent, internationally recognized environmental organization.

In the event of partial implementation (e.g., limited to specific regions or sectors), the question will resolve as Yes only if there is a clear, government-confirmed plan for nationwide coverage by the end of 2030.

P.title: Will the integration of information technology in education significantly reduce the global digital divide by 2030?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, there is a significant reduction in the global digital divide as a result of the integration of information technology in education. A significant reduction is defined as:
- At least a 50% decrease in the number of individuals worldwide without access to digital devices and the internet.
- A measurable improvement in digital literacy rates across all age groups, particularly in underdeveloped and developing countries.

The assessment of the global digital divide will be based on reports and data from authoritative sources such as the United Nations, World Bank, International Telecommunication Union (ITU), and UNESCO. The integration of information technology in education includes, but is not limited to, the provision of digital devices, internet access, digital literacy programs, and online learning platforms.

In the absence of clear data, a consensus among at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) or a publication in a peer-reviewed journal will be sufficient for resolution. The question will resolve as No if these criteria are not met by the specified date.

Q.title: Will a new infectious disease emerge with a global infection rate exceeding 1% before 2030?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, a new infectious disease emerges with a global infection rate exceeding 1% of the world's population. The infection rate must be confirmed by the World Health Organization (WHO) or the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). For the purpose of this question, a "new infectious disease" refers to a pathogen not previously identified in humans before the date of this question. The global infection rate is defined as the percentage of the world's population confirmed to be infected by the disease, as reported by the WHO or CDC. In the absence of direct reports from these organizations, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) will be considered sufficient. In the event of conflicting reports, the average of the reported rates from these sources will be used to determine the resolution. This question does not consider the severity of the disease or the death rate, focusing solely on the infection rate.

P.title: Will the United States enter a recession before 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, the United States officially enters a recession. A recession is defined as two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth as reported by the Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA) of the U.S. Department of Commerce. The determination of a recession by the National Bureau of Economic Research (NBER), which is considered the authoritative body on U.S. recessions, will also result in a Yes resolution. In the absence of an official declaration, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) confirming the recession will be sufficient for resolution. This question resolves as NO if these conditions are not met by the specified date.

Q.title: Will California introduce groundbreaking legislation on digital privacy by 2025?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, California has officially introduced legislation that is recognized as groundbreaking in the field of digital privacy. Groundbreaking legislation is defined as laws that significantly enhance the protection of digital privacy rights beyond the current standards as of 2023, or introduce new rights or mechanisms for the protection of digital data that are not present in existing California law or federal law. The legislation must be passed by the California State Legislature and signed into law by the Governor. Confirmation of such legislation must come from official government announcements or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) are sufficient. Proposed but not enacted legislation, or minor amendments to existing laws, do not count towards this question's resolution.

Groundbreaking legislation is defined as laws that significantly enhance the protection of digital privacy rights beyond the current standards as of 2023, or introduce new rights or mechanisms for the protection of digital data that are not present in existing California law or federal law. The legislation must be passed by the California State Legislature and signed into law by the Governor. Confirmation of such legislation must come from official government announcements or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) are sufficient. Proposed but not enacted legislation, or minor amendments to existing laws, do not count towards this question's resolution.

reasons: Economic conditions, such as a recession, can influence legislative priorities and actions. In times of economic downturn, there may be increased pressure on governments to address economic issues, potentially delaying or deprioritizing other legislative efforts, including those related to digital privacy.

Conversely, a recession might also spur legislative action in areas like digital privacy as part of broader efforts to stimulate the economy or address public concerns heightened by economic instability.

California, being a major economic hub, might have its legislative agenda influenced by broader national economic conditions. A recession could impact the state's budget and resources, which in turn could affect the feasibility and timing of introducing and passing new legislation.
relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, as economic conditions can influence legislative actions and priorities.

verification_result.reasoning: R is a logical disjunction of P and Q because it states that either the United States will enter a recession before 2025 or California will introduce groundbreaking legislation on digital privacy by 2025. This means that R will be true if at least one of P or Q is true.

P.title: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, Ukraine becomes a full member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO). Full membership is defined as the completion of all formal accession processes and the official recognition of Ukraine as a NATO member state by the NATO Secretary General or an official NATO communication. The resolution will be based on official announcements from NATO or the Ukrainian government. In the absence of such announcements, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) will be considered sufficient. In the event of a partial or observer status, or any other form of affiliation that falls short of full membership, the question will resolve as No.

P.title: Will there be a significant breakthrough in social engineering techniques that influence public behavior by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a significant breakthrough in social engineering techniques that has a demonstrable and measurable impact on influencing public behavior is announced. A "significant breakthrough" is defined as a new method or improvement of existing techniques that leads to a substantial change in public behavior, attitudes, or beliefs on a large scale. The breakthrough must be documented in at least one of the following: - A peer-reviewed scientific journal. - An official report by a recognized governmental or international organization. - Coverage by at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). The impact of the breakthrough must be measurable through surveys, studies, or statistical analysis demonstrating a significant change in public behavior, attitudes, or beliefs. In the event of multiple claims of breakthroughs, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one meets the above criteria. Temporary or localized effects do not count towards this question's resolution.

Q.title: Will a significant discovery in space lead to a new economic model or job sector as predicted by the Bureau of Labor Statistics by 2030?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a significant discovery in space leads to the creation of a new economic model or job sector, as predicted or recognized by the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS). A "significant discovery in space" refers to any discovery beyond Earth's atmosphere that has a direct and substantial impact on economic models, job creation, or the restructuring of existing job sectors. The new economic model or job sector must be officially acknowledged by the BLS in their publications or on their official website. In the absence of direct acknowledgment from the BLS, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the economic impact of the discovery will suffice. The discovery must lead to the creation of jobs that did not exist prior to the discovery, and these jobs must be recognized as part of a new sector or economic model. Temporary or speculative job creation does not meet this criterion. The question resolves as Yes only if the new economic model or job sector is operational and recognized by the end of 2030.

P.title: Will a major breakthrough in pharmacology be announced that significantly extends human lifespan by 2030?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a major breakthrough in pharmacology is announced that significantly extends human lifespan. A "major breakthrough" is defined as a pharmacological discovery or development that is scientifically proven to extend the average human lifespan by at least 10 years. The breakthrough must be documented in at least one of the following: 
- A publication in a peer-reviewed scientific journal of high impact. 
- An official announcement from a leading health organization (e.g., World Health Organization, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, National Institutes of Health). 
For the purpose of this question, "significantly extends human lifespan" refers to the extension of life expectancy at birth. The announcement must be supported by clinical trial results that demonstrate the efficacy of the pharmacological intervention in humans. In the absence of such an announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. 
In the event of multiple announcements, the question will resolve based on the first announcement that meets these criteria.

P.title: Will Google announce a significant breakthrough in natural sciences research by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, Google (or any of its subsidiaries) officially announces a significant breakthrough in the field of natural sciences. A "significant breakthrough" is defined as a discovery or development that represents a major advancement in understanding or application in any of the natural sciences (including, but not limited to, biology, chemistry, physics, earth science, and astronomy). The announcement must be made through an official Google press release or a publication in a reputable scientific journal. The breakthrough must be recognized as significant by the scientific community, as evidenced by coverage in at least three major science news outlets (e.g., Scientific American, Nature News, Science Daily) or citations in peer-reviewed scientific journals. In the absence of widespread recognition, the question will resolve as No. The breakthrough must be new, not a continuation or incremental improvement of existing technologies or research.

Q.title: Will a major infectious disease outbreak lead to the implementation of new global health policies by 2025?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a major infectious disease outbreak has led to the implementation of new global health policies. A "major infectious disease outbreak" is defined as an event where a disease causes significant morbidity or mortality in at least three countries across different WHO regions, and is officially declared a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC) by the World Health Organization (WHO).

New global health policies must be adopted by at least five member countries of the United Nations and aim to address the prevention, preparedness, or response to infectious diseases. These policies must be documented in official government publications or announcements. In the absence of such documentation, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) will be considered sufficient evidence.

In the event that multiple outbreaks occur, the question will resolve as Yes if any one of them meets the criteria above.

Q.title: Will the US Congress pass a major law reforming the judicial system before 2030?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, the US Congress passes a major law that significantly reforms the judicial system. A "major law" is defined as legislation that enacts substantial changes in the structure, powers, or processes of the federal judicial system, including but not limited to the Supreme Court, federal courts of appeal, and district courts. 

Substantial changes may include alterations in the appointment process of judges, changes in the jurisdiction of courts, significant modifications in the procedural rules governing litigation, or the introduction of measures aimed at increasing the transparency or accountability of the judiciary. 

The passage of the law must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. 

In the event that multiple pieces of legislation are passed that collectively constitute a major reform, this question will resolve as Yes.

In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The sanctions must be new, distinct from any previous sanctions, and specifically linked to geopolitical conflicts occurring after the date of this question's posting. This question resolves as YES upon the official announcement of the sanctions by the Canadian government or credible confirmation by major news outlets. Otherwise, this question resolves as NO.

Q.title: Will the value of Bitcoin exceed the US dollar in terms of global transaction volume by 2030?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the total global transaction volume of Bitcoin exceeds that of the US dollar within a single calendar year. Transaction volume refers to the total value of all transactions processed over a given time period. This includes but is not limited to purchases, sales, and transfers. The assessment will be based on data reported by authoritative financial institutions or organizations specializing in tracking cryptocurrency and fiat currency transactions, such as the International Monetary Fund (IMF), World Bank, major central banks, or recognized financial market analysis firms. In the absence of direct data, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) will be considered sufficient. The resolution will consider adjustments for inflation and currency valuation changes over the period. In the event of a close call, where the transaction volumes are within a margin of error of 5% or less, the question will resolve as No.

P.title: Will the Republican Party (US) initiate a policy that significantly alters the demographic landscape of the US by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the Republican Party in the United States has initiated and implemented a policy or set of policies that have significantly altered the demographic landscape of the United States. Significant alteration is defined as a measurable change in the composition of the population by age, race, ethnicity, or immigration status, as reported by the United States Census Bureau or another authoritative government body. The policy must lead to a change that is statistically significant compared to trends observed prior to 2023. Changes solely due to natural demographic trends (e.g., aging population) without direct policy influence will not count towards this question's resolution. In the absence of direct government data, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) will be considered sufficient. Policies that are proposed but not implemented, or those in trial phases without full implementation, do not count towards this question's resolution.

Q.title: Will the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announce a new initiative to combat a global health crisis before 2025?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) officially announces a new initiative aimed at combating a global health crisis. The initiative must be specifically designed to address a health issue with the potential to affect a significant portion of the global population. The announcement must be made through an official CDC press release or a public statement by a high-ranking CDC official. In the absence of a direct announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) will be considered sufficient evidence. The initiative must be new, not an extension or modification of existing programs. In the event of ambiguity, the resolution will be based on the consensus of expert opinion in the public health community.
